title: 107_hr2593
content: The Act may be cited as the "Commission to Universally Reduce and Eradicate Disease Act of 2001". The Congress finds that the United States has historically led in defeating totalitarianism and communism, spreading democracy globally, and being a superpower with the ability to establish new goals for the 21st century. Additionally, the US is a leader in research, development, and production of technologies and medicines, including establishing a Center for Vaccine Development at the National Institutes of Health to address global infectious diseases. The United States has the resources, through the National Institutes of Health and the National Science Foundation, to expand health research information globally through the use of Internet conferencing and dissemination of data. The National Commission for the New National Goal: The Advancement of Global Health is established to recommend a national strategy for coordinating health entities to eradicate disease. This includes assisting in global disease control through vaccine development and sharing health research information online. The Commission for the New National Goal: The Advancement of Global Health consists of 15 members, including representatives from public, private, and academic sectors with expertise in areas such as computer sciences, medical research, and the use of the Internet for medical conferencing. Members include officials from the Department of Health and Human Services, Federal Trade Commission, National Institutes of Health, National Science Foundation, and Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The Commission for the New National Goal: The Advancement of Global Health consists of 15 members, including representatives from various sectors with expertise in different areas. Members are appointed by different authorities, including the President, Senate, and House of Representatives. The Commission for the New National Goal: The Advancement of Global Health has 15 members appointed by different authorities. Members serve for life, without pay, and a quorum is nine members. The President designates the Chairperson and Vice Chairperson. The Chairperson of the Commission is appointed by the President. The Commission meets monthly or as called by a majority of its members. The Commission, chaired by the President's appointee, meets monthly or as majority members call. The Commission is granted powers under Section 6. The Commission, chaired by the President's appointee, meets monthly or as majority members call. The Commission may hold hearings, take testimony, receive evidence, and obtain official data from US departments. Members and agents can take actions authorized by the Commission. The Commission can also accept gifts, bequests, or devises to aid its purpose. The Commission, chaired by the President's appointee, meets monthly or as majority members call. It can hold hearings, take testimony, receive evidence, and obtain official data from US departments. Members and agents can take actions authorized by the Commission. The Commission can accept gifts, bequests, or devises to aid its purpose. Gifts and proceeds received will be deposited in the Treasury and available for disbursement upon order of the Chairperson or Commission. Property accepted under this shall be considered a gift to the United States for tax purposes. The Commission may use the United States mails and request administrative support services from the Administrator of General Services on a reimbursable basis. The Commission has the authority to contract with government and private agencies for necessary services without following certain statutes. The Commission may submit interim reports to the President and Congress as deemed appropriate. A final report must be transmitted within 12 months of the Act's enactment, containing findings, conclusions, and recommendations. The Commission will terminate 30 days after submitting the final report. The Act will take effect 60 days after enactment, with authorization for appropriations. Authorization of appropriations up to $1,000,000 for fiscal year 2002 for the National Institutes of Health to coordinate activities with the Commission, National Science Foundation, and other groups to provide information on infectious disease vaccine development and health research on the Internet. Budget Act compliance requires spending authority to be specified in appropriation Acts.
